Award.AwardTitle: Control of Fission Yeast Cell Morphogenesis by Rho GAP Rga4 and the Conserved Protein Kinase Orb6

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although substantial progress has been made in understanding cell morphogenesis, many of the molecular mechanisms involved in this process are still unknown. This project investigates the molecular basis of cell morphogenesis, especially how the dynamics of the cytoskeleton is spatially controlled within the cell.

The fission yeast ser/thr protein kinase, Orb6, which is required for maintenance of cell polarity, belongs to the NDR/LATS family of AGC kinases, whose members play a key role in the control of cell morphology and cell proliferation in several organisms. Currently, there is a very limited understanding of the cellular functions of this conserved kinase family and no knowledge of its target effectors in the control of cell morphogenesis. The objective of this project is to establish the function of Orb6/NDR kinase in the spatial control of Rho GAP Rga4, using a combination of genetic, biochemical and microscopic approaches. The results of this research project will provide targets/effectors of a conserved signaling pathway with implications for morphogenesis and growth control in higher organisms.

The Broader Impacts of this project will be to provide training opportunities for students of different backgrounds and educational levels, including graduate, undergraduate, high school, as well as those participating in a K-8 science outreach program. Because of the specific geographical location of Miami, many students are from different minority backgrounds. The laboratory provides a resource for other researchers in 2-hybrid analysis, yeast genetics and microscopy techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

 

Work from my laboratory supported by this National Science Foundation grant provided insights into a fundamental problem: how cells control their shape. Maintaining a specific shape is very important to ensure that cells work properly, and it is fundamental for the function of kidney cells, neurons, or migrating cells. Abnormal cell shape changes have been observed during the onset of disease.

 

Using fission yeast that can grow from one or two cell ends, we made the important discovery, published in the magazine Science, that the levels of active Cdc42, a key cell shape regulator, oscillate at the cells tips with an average period of five minutes (Figure 1). Our findings demonstrated that Cdc42 activity is regulated at the whole-cell level by positive and negative feedback mechanisms. Our results are consistent with observations describing Cdc42 fluctuations and oscillations in mammalian and plant cells, indicating that this mechanism is conserved. These findings and our mathematical model  provide novel theoretical and experimental tools to understand how Cdc42, an enzyme implicated in organism development and in the onset of disease, is controlled at the global cell level to produce a specific cell shape.

 

Additionally, our work has identified a novel target for the conserved NDR kinase pathway, which controls cell morphogenesis in eukaryotic cells, from yeast to human. The molecular details of this control are still poorly understood.  We found that the fission yeast NDR kinase Orb6 limits the activation of Cdc42 at the site of growth (Figure 3). We have defined the molecular mechanism underpinning this function: Orb6 kinase modifies the Cdc42 activator Gef1 by phosphorylation, promoting Gef1 “entrapment” in the cytoplasm. These findings are of importance because loss of NDR kinase has been associated with abnormal cell shape of neuronal cells and in the development of gastric cancer.

 

Broader impacts of the work

 

           During the past several years our laboratory has offered training opportunities for many students of different backgrounds and educational levels. We have followed a number of high school, undergraduate students, graduate rotation students and postdoctoral fellows.  Many continued their studies as Postdoctoral fellows, Medical or Graduate students in our or other Universities. We routinely hosted undergraduate and high school students during the summer; they were paired with the P.I, the Postdoctoral Fellow or the Assistant Scientist. The work of undergraduate students has been included in publications. Our laboratory is also a resource for other researchers for help with 2-hybrid analysis, yeast genetics and microscopy techniques.  Researchers and students from other laboratories have access to our microscope and imaging facility.  Students particularly enjoy the exposure to the variety of genetic, microscopical, biochemical and biophysical techniques currently employed in our laboratory.

 

Because of the specific geographical location of Miami, many of our students are from different minority backgrounds:  for this reason, the University of Miami was awarded the status of Minority Institution in 2004-2006.
